questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of recurrent lesions on lips as shown in the image below, which is associated with fever. What is the characteristic feature seen in Tzanck smear? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multinucleated giant cells

 

The patient presents with recurrent vesicular lesions on the lips associated with fever, which is characteristic of Herpes labialis caused by the Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1). This condition is often triggered by fever and is hence also called a "fever blister" or "cold sores."

 

Another condition with recurrent lesions at the same site, typically triggered by a particular medication each time the patient is exposed to it is “Fixed Drug Eruption”. But here the initial appearance of vesicles on the lips is noted. These vesicles are prone to rupture. Once ruptured, the vesicles transform into erosions and ulcers with polycyclic margins, characteristic of herpes labialis. A history of fever is important as it often triggers these outbreaks.

 

On a Tzanck smear, the characteristic finding for Herpes labialis is the presence of multinucleated giant cells and acantholytic cells. These multinucleate giant cells are formed by the fusion of infected cells, leading to the appearance of multiple nuclei within a single cell. The Tzanck smear is specifically used in dermatology to diagnose viral infections, particularly Herpes simplex and Varicella-zoster.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Henderson Patterson bodies: These are eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies seen in Molluscum contagiosum, a viral infection caused by a poxvirus. These are not associated with Herpes labialis and are not found on a Tzanck smear for this condition.

 

 

Option C. Acanthocytes: These are spiny red blood cells that are typically seen in liver diseases such as cirrhosis and in certain neurological disorders. They are not related to the findings in a Tzanck smear or Herpes labialis. Although "acantholytic cells" can also be seen in Herpes labialis, these are different from acanthocytes.

 

 

Option D. Owl eye appearance: This term describes the characteristic appearance of cells infected by Cytomegalovirus (CMV), where the nucleus shows a large inclusion giving it an "owl eye" look. This is not a feature of Herpes labialis and would not be seen on a Tzanck smear for this condition.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of multinucleated giant cells on a Tzanck smear is the characteristic diagnostic feature for Herpes labialis (HSV-1).

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset of chest pain shooting to the neck and interscapular region. X-ray shows widened mediastinum. BP is 110/90 mmHg in the right upper limb and 160/100 mmHg in the left upper limb. What is the most likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute aortic dissection

 

  • Patient with sudden-onset severe chest pain, with a difference in blood pressure between the two limbs, and a widened mediastinum on x-ray suggests a diagnosis of acute aortic dissection.
  • AORTIC DISSECTION is tear in intima of aorta

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS): ACS includes conditions such as myocardial infarction and unstable angina. These conditions typically present with chest pain but do not usually cause blood pressure discrepancies between limbs or a widened mediastinum.

 

Option B. Acute Pulmonary Embolism: Pulmonary embolism presents with sudden onset dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, and signs of right heart strain. It does not typically present with blood pressure discrepancies between limbs or a widened mediastinum.

 

Option D. Esophageal Rupture: Esophageal rupture can present with severe chest pain, subcutaneous emphysema, and signs of sepsis. It does not typically present with blood pressure discrepancies between limbs. It may cause mediastinal widening but would more likely present with other signs such as subcutaneous emphysema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The classic presentation of acute aortic dissection includes sudden severe chest pain radiating to the neck and back, a discrepancy in blood pressure between the limbs, and a widened mediastinum on chest X-ray.
  • Immediate imaging with a CT thoracic angiogram and lowering blood pressure are crucial steps in management.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the OPD with a parietal swelling present since birth. An X-ray was ordered and is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cephalhematoma

 

Cephalohematomas are traumatic subperiosteal hematoma of the skull that are usually caused by birth injury. They are bound between the periosteum and cranium, and therefore cannot cross sutures. Being bound by a suture line distinguishes them from subgaleal hematoma, which can cross sutures.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subgaleal hematoma: This hematoma is located beneath the scalp's aponeurotic layer and can spread widely over the skull, which is not confined by suture lines. Therefore, it is less likely to present as a localized swelling.

 

Option C. Encephalocele: This is a neural tube defect characterized by the herniation of brain tissue through a defect in the skull. It is usually more severe and associated with neurological deficits.

 

Option D. Caput Succedaneum: This refers to swelling of the soft tissues of the scalp, which develops as the baby travels through the birth canal. This swelling can cross suture lines and typically resolves without intervention within the first few days of life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cephalhematoma is a localized hematoma under the periosteum of the skull bone in newborns, confined by suture lines and typically associated with birth trauma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with painful oral mucosal lesions and blisters on her skin. A biopsy is performed, and direct immunofluorescence microscopy is used to examine the skin specimen. Based on this finding, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pemphigus vulgaris

 

Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by painful mucosal lesions and skin blisters.

 

The direct immunofluorescence (DIF) image shows a characteristic "fishnet" or "chicken-wire" pattern due to IgG antibodies against desmoglein 1 and 3, which are components of the desmosomes that connect epidermal cells.

 

The disruption of these desmosomes leads to acantholysis and intraepidermal blister formation, as seen in pemphigus vulgaris. The presence of painful oral lesions further supports this diagnosis, as they are commonly seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bullous pemphigoid: This condition also presents with blisters but typically in older patients without mucosal involvement. DIF shows a linear pattern of IgG and C3 at the basement membrane zone, not the fishnet pattern seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

 

Option C. Dermatitis herpetiformis: This condition is characterized by intensely pruritic vesicles and papules, typically on extensor surfaces. DIF shows granular IgA deposits in the dermal papillae, which is different from the fishnet pattern seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Option D. Lupus vulgaris: This is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis presenting with slow-growing reddish-brown nodules, not blisters. It does not show a fishnet pattern on DIF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris presents with painful oral lesions and skin blisters, and its hallmark DIF finding is the fishnet pattern due to antibodies against desmoglein 1 and 3.

questions.text: A morbidly obese patient underwent cholecystectomy and subsequently complained of pain in the legs after walking for some distance. Which investigation would be most appropriate for further evaluation? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Duplex scan 

 

The patient's symptoms suggest occurrence of post operative Deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The investigations listed are used to evaluate vascular conditions:

 

This ultrasound-based diagnostic technique combines traditional ultrasound to visualize the structure of the blood vessels and Doppler ultrasound to visualize blood flow within the vessels. It is the first-line investigation for DVT as it is non-invasive, widely available, and cost-effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI angiography: Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) is a type of MRI that visualizes blood vessels. It is a good non-invasive option to visualize blood flow and vascular anatomy but is less commonly used as a first-line test due to cost and availability.

 

Option C. CT angiography: This imaging modality uses computed tomography (CT) combined with a contrast agent to visualize vascular structures. It's useful in detailed mapping of blood vessels but exposes the patient to radiation and contrast, which may not be suitable for all patients.

 

Option D. USG: Ultrasound (USG) is useful for various diagnostic purposes but on its own may not be sufficient for a full vascular assessment in the case of DVT unless it's part of a duplex scan.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

For a morbidly obese patient presenting with leg pain consistent with DVT post-cholecystectomy, a duplex scan is the most appropriate initial investigation to evaluate for DVT.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a history of bronchial asthma in third stage of labor. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in the management of postpartum hemorrhage in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carboprost

 

The drug that should be avoided in this patient with a history of bronchial asthma is carboprost since it can cause bronchoconstriction.

 

Carboprost (PGF2α analogue)

 

Action - It increases uterine tone by contracting upper segment of uterus

 

Use - To control postpartum hemorrhage (DOC – Oxytocin).

 

A/E - Vomiting, diarrhea, and bronchoconstriction.

 

Contraindications -

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is the first-line drug to prevent and treat PPH and also used in augmentation of labour according to WHO guidelines. Administered by intravenous route and may lead to hypotension and reflex tachycardia.

 

Option C. Dinoprostone: Dinoprostone is a PGE2 analogue used for cervical ripening, induction of labor, and in atony treatment. It should be avoided in patients with a history of asthma, glaucoma, or myocardial infarction. One major adverse effect is uterine hyperstimulation.

 

Option D. Methyl ergometrine: Ergot derivatives are used in the control of postpartum uterine bleeding. It is given intramuscularly and is effective within 1-5 minutes. It is given at the time of delivery of the placenta or immediately after if bleeding is significant. Side effects are gastrointestinal disturbances like diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carboprost should be avoided in the management of postpartum hemorrhage in patients with a history of bronchial asthma due to its potential to cause bronchoconstriction.

questions.text: Stellate granuloma is seen in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cat scratch disease

 

Stellate granuloma is seen in cat-scratch disease. It is also called as subacute regional lymphadenitis.

 

It is a bacterial infection caused by Bartonella henselae. Acquired following contact with infected animals (commonly cats).

 

Regional lymph nodes demonstrate:

 

  • Follicular hyperplasia with circumscribed central stellate necrosis with neutrophils
  • Surrounded by palisading histiocytes (suppurative granulomas)
  • Sinuses packed with monocytoid B cells
  • Usually, there are no perifollicular and intrafollicular epithelioid cells

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is undergoing evaluation for successive recurrent pregnancy losses. On ultrasound, a Mullerian anomaly is suspected. What is the BEST way to confirm this? (NEET PF 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hysteroscopy + laparoscopy

 

Explanation:

 

Hysteroscopy + laparoscopy:

 

  • Hysteroscopy combined with laparoscopy is considered the best invasive method to confirm the diagnosis of Mullerian anomalies. This approach allows direct visualization of both the internal and external contours of the uterus.
  • During the procedure, hysteroscopy can evaluate the endometrial cavity, while laparoscopy can assess the external uterine surface and other pelvic structures.
  • This combination not only confirms the diagnosis but also allows for simultaneous corrective surgery, if necessary (e.g., resecting a uterine septum).

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Hysterosalpingography: Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is a useful imaging technique for evaluating the shape and patency of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes. However, it may not provide detailed information about the external contour of the uterus or distinguish between certain types of Mullerian anomalies.

 

Option C. Laparoscopy: While laparoscopy alone can provide information about the external structure of the uterus and other pelvic organs, it does not allow for direct visualization of the endometrial cavity. Combining it with hysteroscopy gives a more comprehensive assessment.

 

Option D. Transvaginal sonography: Transvaginal sonography (TVS) is a non-invasive imaging technique that can detect many uterine anomalies. However, it may not be as definitive as hysteroscopy combined with laparoscopy, especially for complex anomalies.

 

Educational Objective

 

The best way to confirm a suspected Mullerian anomaly is through hysteroscopy combined with laparoscopy, which allows for a comprehensive assessment and potential simultaneous treatment.

 

Ref: Page no 32, DC Duttas Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: Adverse effect of bleomycin on which system can be worsened by radiation therapy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulmonary

 

Explanation:

 

Bleomycin is metabolized by bleomycin hydrolase enzyme which is deficient in lungs and skin. This makes these two organs most susceptible to bleomycin toxicity. 

 

In lungs, bleomycin causes pulmonary fibrosis. When combined with radiation therapy, pulmonary fibrosis can be significantly worsened as radiation itself can cause lung damage and fibrosis. This makes pulmonary toxicity a major concern when using bleomycin with radiation therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Skin: While skin is also susceptible to bleomycin toxicity due to deficiency of bleomycin hydrolase (causing flagellated pigmentation), radiation therapy does not specifically worsen the cutaneous side effects.

 

 

Option B. Nerves: Bleomycin does not have significant neurotoxicity as its main adverse effects. Radiation therapy does not interact with bleomycin to cause neurological problems.

 

Option D. Gastric: Bleomycin does not have significant gastrointestinal toxicity as a major side effect. Radiation therapy does not specifically worsen any gastrointestinal effects of bleomycin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bleomycin is Metabolized by bleomycin hydrolase which is Deficient at

questions.text: A female patient with infertility presented to the clinic and underwent karyotyping. What is the likely diagnosis in the karyotype shown? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Turner syndrome

 

The karyotype image shows 45 chromosomes with a single X chromosome and no second sex chromosome, confirming a 45, XO karyotype, which is characteristic of Turner syndrome.

 

Turner syndrome is a condition caused by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome, leading to the absence of one X chromosome. This genetic abnormality is commonly associated with infertility, short stature, webbed neck, and a variety of other clinical features.

 

Turner syndrome is a common cause of primary amenorrhea due to ovarian dysgenesis (underdeveloped ovaries), which leads to hormonal imbalances that prevent normal menstruation and fertility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Down syndrome: Down syndrome, or trisomy 21, is characterized by an extra chromosome 21, resulting in 47 chromosomes. It is associated with intellectual disability, distinctive facial features, and other health complications, not infertility related to the absence of an X chromosome.

 

Option C. Klinefelter syndrome: Klinefelter syndrome occurs in males with a 47, XXY karyotype. Patients typically have an extra X chromosome and may present with infertility, gynecomastia, and tall stature. It does not occur in females and does not present as 45, XO.

 

Option D. Edward syndrome: Edward syndrome, or trisomy 18, is characterized by an extra chromosome 18, leading to 47 chromosomes. It presents with severe developmental delays and congenital abnormalities. It is unrelated to the XO karyotype seen in Turner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by a 45, XO karyotype, where there is a complete or partial absence of the second X chromosome, leading to infertility, primary amenorrhea, and other characteristic features.

choices.text: Brain utilization of ketone bodies increases

questions.text: Which of the following metabolic changes does not occur during prolonged fasting compared to fasting for 12-36 hours? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Liver gluconeogenesis increases

 

Explanation:

 

During prolonged fasting, liver gluconeogenesis actually doesn't increase compared to short-term fasting (12-36 hours). As fasting progresses, the body adapts to spare protein by decreasing the rate of gluconeogenesis. While gluconeogenesis remains active to supply glucose for glucose-dependent tissues, the overall rate doesn't increase because peripheral tissues decrease their glucose demands. The brain increasingly switches to using ketone bodies for energy (up to ~60% of its needs), which reduces the demand for glucose produced by gluconeogenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brain utilization of ketone bodies increases: This is correct. During prolonged fasting, the brain adapts to using ketone bodies for its energy needs, reducing its dependence on glucose. This is a critical adaptation that helps spare body protein by reducing the need for gluconeogenesis from amino acids.

 

Option C. Urea production rate decreases: This is correct. As fasting progresses, protein breakdown decreases to conserve vital protein stores. This results in decreased amino acid catabolism, leading to lower rates of urea production and excretion compared to short-term fasting.

 

Option D. Blood glucose production declines: This is correct. Total glucose production decreases during prolonged fasting compared to short-term fasting. This is due to adaptations including increased ketone body utilization by the brain and other tissues becoming more efficient at using fatty acids as fuel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During prolonged fasting, the body prioritizes protein conservation by reducing the rate of gluconeogenesis, while simultaneously increasing ketone body production and utilization, particularly by the brain, leading to an overall decline in glucose production compared to shorter periods of fasting.

questions.text: Which classification method does not take height into consideration as a parameter? [NEET PG 2016]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Corpulence Index

 

  • The Corpulence Index is calculated as the ratio of actual weight to desirable weight and is expressed as "Actual weight/Desirable weight."
  • This index should not exceed 1.2. The formula itself does not directly incorporate height as a parameter in its calculation, unlike the other indices mentioned which explicitly use height in their formulas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Quetelet's Index (Body Mass Index) - This index explicitly uses height as a parameter in its formula: Weight (kg)/Height² (m). Height is a squared term in the denominator.

 

Option B. Broca's Index - This index directly uses height in its formula, calculated as Height (cm) minus 100. For example, if a person's height is 160 cm, their ideal weight according to Broca's index would be (160-100) = 60 kg.

 

Option C. Ponderal Index - This index incorporates height as a key parameter in its calculation: Height (cm)/Cube root of body weight (kg). Height appears in the numerator of the formula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When assessing obesity classification methods, it's important to understand the specific anthropometric measurements each index utilizes, as this affects their applicability and sensitivity in different clinical scenarios. The Corpulence Index stands apart from the others by not directly using height in its formula.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best treatment for idiopathic thrombocytic purpura? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Splenectomy

 

Splenectomy is considered the best long-term treatment option for patients with chronic ITP who do not respond to medical therapies such as steroids or immunoglobulins. The procedure involves removing the spleen, which is a site of platelet destruction in ITP. Removing the spleen often results in a permanent increase in platelet count, though it is typically reserved for patients who are refractory to first-line treatments.

 

Approach to ITP:

 

If severe ITP @ presentation: Transfusion+ steroids

 

  • Intracranial/GI Bleed
  • PC < 5k
  • Large oral bleed/Retinal bleed

 

Low dose steroids recommended in all cases of ITP.

 

If steroid unresponsive, decision depends on duration:

 

  1. Persistent (3-12 months): Rituximab vs TPO-RA (Romiplostim (S. C.), Eltrombopag (Oral)
  2. Chronic (>12 months): Rituximab vs Splenectomy vs TPO-RA

 

If still persistent/refractory, possible options are:

 

  • Fostamatinib: SyK (Tyrosine kinase inhibitor)
  • MMF/Cyclophosphamide/Azathioprine
  • Autologous stem cell transplant

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV immunoglobulins: Used as a first-line treatment, especially for acute cases of ITP or in severe cases to quickly raise the platelet count, but not as a long-term solution.

 

Option B. Steroids: Common first-line treatment for ITP that can effectively increase platelet count in many patients, though many eventually relapse upon discontinuation or become steroid-dependent.

 

Option D. Blood transfusion: Generally not a primary treatment for ITP since the issue is not the quantity of produced platelets but their premature destruction; transfusions might be used in acute, severe bleeding scenarios but do not address the underlying autoimmune process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Splenectomy is often considered the best treatment option for chronic or refractory idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura, particularly when other treatments such as steroids and IV immunoglobulins fail to maintain a safe platelet count or cause side effects that are difficult to manage.

 

Reference: ASH 2021 summary

questions.text: Number of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age group per year is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) GFR

 

The General Fertility Rate (GFR) is a demographic measure that indicates the number of live births per 1,000 women of reproductive age (typically aged 15-49) in a given year. It is a more specific measure of fertility than the Crude Birth Rate (CBR) because it focuses only on women in their reproductive years rather than the entire population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TFR (Total Fertility Rate): This measure represents the average number of total children a woman would have during her entire reproductive lifespan (15-49 years), assuming she experiences the current age-specific fertility rates throughout her life.

 

Option B. GRR (Gross Reproduction Rate): GRR refers to the total number of daughters a woman would have during her reproductive life span, assuming no mortality and the current age-specific fertility rates.

 

Option C. NRR (Net Reproduction Rate): NRR is similar to GRR, but it accounts for mortality. It indicates the number of daughters a woman would have who would survive to the end of their reproductive period, given the current mortality rates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The General Fertility Rate (GFR) is the number of live births per 1,000 women of reproductive age (15-49 years) in a given year, making it a key measure of fertility in a population.

 

Note –

 

  • TFR is also known as completed family size.
  • To achieve NRR 1, couple protection rate should be more than 60%, which is already achieved
  • Best contraceptive advisable is vasectomy (sterilization).
  • As per NFHS 5, TFR goal was 2.1, India have already achieved the replacement level (TFR 2)

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in Static Two-point discrimination? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Merkel disk

 

Static two-point discrimination requires a receptor that adapts very slowly to maintain sensation over a prolonged period. Merkel cells are crucial for this function.

 

Merkel cells:

 

  • They are slow-adapting receptors
  • Excellent for 2-point discrimination
  • Have a less receptive field
  • Critical for detecting edges and points
  • Particularly important for tasks like Braille reading

 

The key characteristics that make Merkel cells ideal for static two-point discrimination are:

 

  1. Slow adaptation rate
  2. Ability to detect steady stimuli
  3. Precise localization of sensory input

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Meissner's corpuscles: Incorrect. These are rapidly adapting receptors, making them unsuitable for static discrimination. They are best for fine touch sensations.

 

Option C. Pacinian corpuscles: Incorrect. These are rapidly adapting receptors present at Deep dermis, joint capsule that sense high-frequency vibration and pressure, not static stimuli.

 

Option D. Ruffini ending: Incorrect. While these are slow-adapting mechanoreceptors, they primarily sense stretch and sustained pressure, not precise point discrimination.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which mosquito is commonly found in urban areas? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans.  (a) Anopheles Stephensi

 

  • Anopheles Stephensi is predominantly found in urban areas. This mosquito species has adapted well to urban environments and commonly breeds in overhead tanks, cisterns, and other artificial water containers typical in cities. 
  • It thrives in clean water collections found in urban infrastructure, making it the primary Anopheles species in urban settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anopheles Gambiae: This species is primarily found in Africa and not typically associated with urban environments in the Asian context.

 

Option C. Anopheles Culicifacies: This is predominantly a rural vector in India. It typically breeds in clean water bodies like streams and irrigation channels in agricultural settings.

 

Option D. Anopheles Baimaii: This species is mainly found in forest and forest-fringe areas, preferring natural breeding sites rather than urban environments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vector mosquitoes have specific ecological niches and breeding preferences. Anopheles Stephensi's adaptation to urban environments makes it particularly important for malaria control programs in cities, where it utilizes man-made clean water collections for breeding.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of depression was initially being treated with sertraline, but his symptoms were not adequately controlled. His medication regimen was changed to include an MAO inhibitor and amitriptyline. Shortly after the change in medication, the patient developed agitation, seizures, hyperreflexia, and tremors. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cyproheptadine

 

This patient has developed serotonin syndrome, a potentially life-threatening condition that can occur when medications that increase serotonin levels, such as an SSRI (sertraline) combined with an MAO inhibitor and a tricyclic antidepressant (amitriptyline), are used together. The excessive serotonin activity in the central nervous system leads to (serotonin syndrome) symptoms like agitation, seizures, hyperreflexia, and tremors.

 

Cyproheptadine is an antihistamine with strong serotonin antagonistic properties and is used as the treatment of choice in serotonin syndrome. It helps to counteract the excess serotonin and alleviate the symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lorazepam: While lorazepam can help control seizures associated with serotonin syndrome, it does not address the underlying cause, which is the excess serotonin. Therefore, it is not the most appropriate treatment on its own.

 

Option C. L-carnitine: L-carnitine is used in cases of valproate-induced hepatotoxicity and hyperammonemia. It has no role in treating serotonin syndrome.

 

Option D. Leucovorin: Leucovorin is used to counteract the toxic effects of methotrexate and has no relevance in the management of serotonin syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment for serotonin syndrome: Cyproheptadine, a serotonin antagonist; Ketanserin

choices.text: The defective gene for adult type 1 disease is located on Chromosome 16
The defective protein in the Autosomal Recessive type is Polycystin
Adult type 1 disease is more common than adult type 2

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Polycystic Kidney Disease is incorrect? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. The defective protein in the Autosomal Recessive type is Polycystin

 

Explanation:

 

The defective protein in Autosomal Recessive Polycystic Kidney Disease (ARPKD) is Fibrocystin, not Polycystin. ARPKD is associated with the PKHD1 gene that encodes Fibrocystin. This differs fundamentally from ADPKD, where PKD1 and PKD2 genes encode Polycystin 1 (PC1) and Polycystin 2 (PC2). The two forms of polycystic kidney disease have different genetic bases, clinical presentations, and ages of onset.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The defective gene for adult type 1 disease (ADPKD type 1) is located on Chromosome 16. This is the PKD1 gene that encodes Polycystin 1.

 

Option C . Adult type 1 disease (ADPKD type 1) is more common than adult type 2 disease (ADPKD type 2). PKD1 gene mutations account for approximately 85% of ADPKD cases, while PKD2 accounts for the remaining 15%.

 

Option D is incorrect because option B contains an error

 

Educational Objective:

 

Autosomal dominant and recessive forms of polycystic kidney disease involve different genetic mutations affecting different proteins - ADPKD involves mutations in PKD1 or PKD2 genes encoding polycystins, while ARPKD involves mutations in PKHD1 gene encoding fibrocystin, with distinct clinical presentations and age of onset.

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV positive patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral candidiasis

 

The most likely diagnosis of the given clinical scenario is oral candidiasis.

 

  • Oral candidiasis or thrush is a patchy, pseudomembranous lesion that develops over the tongue, lips, gum or palate. It is composed of epithelial cells, yeasts, and pseudohyphae. The causative agent is usually Candida albicans.
  • The commonly implemented methods for identifying Candida are 10% potassium hydroxide stain and culture with sabouraud dextrose agar. Differentiation of specific species is possible with special culture mediums like CHROMagar Candida. 
  • ELISA and PCR tests are used in cases of invasive candidiasis and to differentiate Candida dubliniensis from Candida albicans.
  • It occurs in almost all individuals with AIDS. Other risk factors include hyperglycemia, cellular immunodeficiency, corticosteroids or antibiotics.
  • It is treated with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole or fluconazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hairy leukoplakia is a wart-like growth on the tongue, caused by Epstein Barr virus. It is commonly seen as a white lesion on the lateral side of the tongue.

 

Option C. Lichen planus is a pruritic disease characterized by papules commonly seen over the flexor surfaces and trunk. Oral and vulvovaginal lesions may also occur. Oral lesions appear as lacy, white, and raised lesions.

 

Option D. Diphtheria is characterized by the presence of a grey pseudo membrane covering the tonsils and pharynx. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

Educational Objective

 

Oral candidiasis is a common opportunistic infection in HIV-positive individuals, characterized by white, patchy lesions in the oral cavity and the presence of Candida species on microscopic examination. Recognizing this condition and distinguishing it from other oral lesions based on clinical presentation and risk factors is crucial for appropriate management, which may include antifungal therapies like nystatin, ketoconazole, or fluconazole.

choices.text: Place them in same plastic bag and seat it for preservation
Preserve in envelope or paper bag
Fold the handkerchiefs in such a manner that the stained edges come together
Place them in different plastic bags and seal for preservation

questions.text: 2 handkerchiefs with blood stains are found at a crime scene. What is the most appropriate procedure for handling these items? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Preserve in envelope or paper bag

 

When handling blood-stained handkerchiefs or any other stained items found at a crime scene, it is crucial to follow the appropriate procedure to ensure the preservation of evidence. The most suitable method is to preserve the handkerchiefs in an envelope or paper bag, which allows for air circulation. This prevents the growth of mold and bacteria that can occur when moisture is trapped in non-porous containers like plastic bags.

 

Additionally, it is important to dry the stains, but this should be done in the shade or by air drying. Exposing the stains to direct sunlight or heat can denature the DNA, compromising the evidence. Therefore, using a spirit lamp or any other heating material to dry the stains is not recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A & D. Place them in same/different plastic bag and seal it for preservation: Plastic bags should be avoided as they can trap moisture, leading to the growth of mold and bacteria, which can compromise the evidence.

 

Option. C. Fold the handkerchiefs in such a manner that the stained edges come together: Folding the handkerchiefs with the stained edges together can lead to the mixing of stains, making it difficult to distinguish between the stains from different individuals, if applicable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When handling blood-stained items found at a crime scene, preserve them in an envelope or paper bag to allow for air circulation, and dry the stains in the shade or by air drying to prevent DNA denaturation. Avoid using plastic bags or exposing the stains to direct sunlight or heat.

questions.text: Which one is not a criterion for Kawasaki disease? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Purulent conjunctivitis

 

Purulent conjunctivitis is not a criterion for Kawasaki disease. Instead, the conjunctivitis seen in Kawasaki disease is non-purulent and sterile, meaning it does not produce pus, and cultures are negative.

 

Kawasaki disease is an acute, self-limited vasculitis that predominantly affects children. The diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease include the presence of fever for at least five days, along with at least four of the following five clinical features:

 

  1. Bilateral non-purulent conjunctival injection (conjunctivitis): This is a common feature in Kawasaki disease, but it is non-purulent (does not produce pus).
  2. Changes in the lips and oral cavity: This includes strawberry tongue (a red, bumpy tongue), erythema, and cracking of the lips.
  3. Polymorphous rash: A rash of various forms can be present.
  4. Cervical lymphadenopathy: Typically unilateral and larger than 1.5 cm in diameter.
  5. Changes in the extremities: This includes erythema of the palms and soles, edema of the hands and feet, and later desquamation (peeling) of the skin.

 

TOC - IVIG (Intravenous Immunoglobulin) ± Aspirin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rash: A polymorphous rash is one of the key diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease.

 

Option C. Lymphadenopathy: Cervical lymphadenopathy is another diagnostic criterion, usually unilateral and larger than 1.5 cm.

 

Option D. Strawberry tongue: Changes in the lips and oral cavity, including strawberry tongue, are diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kawasaki disease is diagnosed based on a set of clinical criteria, including non-purulent conjunctivitis, rash, lymphadenopathy, and changes in the oral cavity such as strawberry tongue. Purulent conjunctivitis is not a feature of Kawasaki disease.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is not compliant with spectacles for her myopic astigmatism. What would be the appropriate management in her case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Spherical equivalent spectacles

 

The appropriate management for myopic astigmatism in a 15-year-old girl (<18 years) would be spherical equivalent spectacles.

 

The three components of prescription in astigmatism are:

 

  • Power of the spherical component, indicated by a positive (+) or negative (-) dioptre sphere (DS)
  • Power of the cylindrical component, indicated by a positive (+) or negative (-) dioptre cylinder (DC)
  • Axis or orientation of the cylinder.

 

The cylindrical power and axis are correcting the astigmatic part of the refractive error. If an astigmatic eye were to be corrected with a spherical lens alone, the result would be a blur circle on the retina, called the circle of least confusion.

 

The spherical lens power places the circle of least confusion on the retina and is called the spherical equivalent. It is defined as the spherical power whose focal point coincides with the circle of least confusion, where one would see minimal blurring in their vision.
 

 

For example, for spherical power is +2 and cylindrical power is +3,

Spherical equivalent = +2.00 +(+3.00 /2) = +3.50.

 

Spherical equivalent spectacles are given if one has to give less cylinder power than was measured.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. and C - LASIK and Femto LASIK: should be done in patients above 18 years of age.

 

Option D. Implantable Collamer lens: is indicated for patients 21-45 years of age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgical interventions like LASIK and Femto LASIK are not recommended for individuals under 18 years of age.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl went out playing. After coming home, she looked confused. Parents brought her to the hospital, and on examination, she looked irritable and has not passed urine since morning. Her friends said she had something while playing. Which of the following is the likely intoxication and the correct antidote? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Datura; Physostigmine

 

The clinical presentation suggests anticholinergic toxicity, characterized by confusion, irritability, and urinary retention. Datura, commonly known as jimsonweed or thorn apple, contains tropane alkaloids like atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine, which cause anticholinergic symptoms.

 

Anticholinergic toxicity manifests with:

 

  • Central nervous system effects: confusion, hallucinations, irritability
  • Peripheral effects: dry mouth, urinary retention, constipation, tachycardia, hyperthermia

 

The appropriate antidote for anticholinergic toxicity is a cholinergic drug like physostigmine, which increases the levels of acetylcholine by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yellow oleander; Physostigmine: Yellow oleander poisoning involves cardiac glycosides similar to digoxin, which can cause bradycardia, hyperkalemia, and gastrointestinal symptoms. The antidote for oleander poisoning is Digibind, not physostigmine.

 

Option B. Datura; Digibind: While datura poisoning is correctly identified here, Digibind is the antidote for digoxin or digitalis toxicity, not anticholinergic toxicity caused by datura.

 

Option C. Yellow oleander; Digibind: This option correctly pairs yellow oleander poisoning with its antidote, Digibind. However, the clinical presentation does not fit yellow oleander poisoning, which typically involves bradycardia and gastrointestinal symptoms rather than confusion and urinary retention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Datura poisoning causes anticholinergic toxicity, characterized by confusion, urinary retention, and other anticholinergic symptoms. The antidote for such toxicity is physostigmine, a cholinergic agent that increases acetylcholine levels by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase.

questions.text: Recommended minimum per capita space for a factory worker as per The Factory Act 1948 is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 500 cu feet

 

The Factory Act of 1948 is a key piece of legislation in India that governs the working conditions in factories. The recommended minimum per capita space for a factory worker according to this act is 500 cubic feet. This requirement is essential to ensure adequate ventilation and prevent the spread of communicable diseases, as well as to improve overall working conditions.

 

The Factories Act, 1948

 

  • Scope: The Act defines factory as an establishment employing 10 or more persons where power is used and 20 or more persons where power is not used
  • Work related norms:
    • Employment of young persons:
      • Employment prohibited for age less than 14 years
      • 15-18 years old adolescents to be declared fit by ‘certifying surgeons’; will work only between 6AM to 7PM
      • Employment prohibited in certain dangerous occupations
    • Hours of work:
      • A maximum of 4½ hours of work per day for adolescents
      • 48 hours per week (9 hrs per day)
      • Maximum 60 hours per week (including overtime)
    • Leave with wages:
      • 1 day per 15 days of work for adolescents
      • Leaves can be accumulated up to 40 days
    • Health, Safety and Welfare recommendations:
      • A minimum of 500 cubic feet space per worker
      • 1 Safety Officer per 1000 workers
      • 1 Welfare Officer per 500 workers
      • 1 Canteen for greater than 250 workers
      • 1 Crèche for greater than 30 women workers
    • Under Factories Act 1948, there are 29 diseases which are notifiable (Schedule 3): Silicosis; Anthracosis; Byssinosis and Asbestosis
    • Exclusions from the Factory Act: The act does not apply to four specific sectors: the defense sector, mines, railways, and food joints or eateries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recommended spaces:

 

  • Floor space per person in a house: minimum 70 – 90 sq. ft.
  • Floor area per student in a class: > 10 sq. ft.
  • Space per worker in a factory (The Factory Act, 1948): >500 cu. ft.t

questions.text: Identify the Mallampati class of this patient? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Class II

 

The image shows a Mallampati class II airway.

 

  • The Mallampati classification, sometimes referred to as the Mallampati score or Mallampati test, is a system used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation. It correlates the visibility of the base of the uvula, faucial pillars, and the soft palate with the ease of laryngeal visualization and intubation.
  • Class I: Hard palate, Soft palate, entire uvula, and tonsillar pillars are visible.
  • Class II: Hard palate, Soft palate and base of the uvula are visible.
  • Class III: Only hard palate and  soft palate is visible.
  • Class IV: Only hard palate is visible.

 

 

The primary purpose of the Mallampati classification is to assess the potential difficulty of intubation in patients prior to surgery or in any other situation requiring airway management. A higher Mallampati score generally indicates a more challenging intubation. Anesthesiologists and surgeons use the Mallampati classification as a component of the preoperative airway assessment. This assessment helps them to be prepared for potential airway challenges during surgery and determine if specialized equipment or techniques might be necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Class I: This classification is incorrect as the image does not show all the structures visible in Class I, such as the uvula and pillars.

 

Option C. Class IV: This classification is incorrect because the image does not show only the hard palate, which would be indicative of Class IV.

 

Option D. Class III: This classification is incorrect as the image shows more structures than what would be visible in Class III, where only the soft palate is visible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mallampati classification is a useful tool for predicting the difficulty of intubation, with higher classes indicating more challenging airways. The image provided corresponds to Mallampati class II, where the soft palate and base of the uvula are visible.

questions.text: In the given image, the tendon marked by the arrow is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flexor carpi radialis

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the anterior compartment of the forearm, focusing on the tendons near the wrist. The arrow is pointing to a tendon that runs from the forearm to the wrist and to the palm. This tendon belongs to the flexor carpi radialis muscle. The flexor carpi radialis is one of the superficial flexor muscles of the forearm. It plays a crucial role in flexion and abduction of the wrist.

 

Flexor Carpi Radialis: The flexor carpi radialis tendon is located just lateral to the palmaris longus tendon. It is prominent and easily palpable in many individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flexor carpi ulnaris: This is incorrect. The flexor carpi ulnaris tendon is located medial to the palmaris longus tendon and runs towards the pisiform bone.

 

Option C. Flexor digitorum superficialis: This is incorrect. The flexor digitorum superficialis tendons are deeper and run to the fingers, responsible for flexion of the middle phalanges.

 

Option D. Palmaris longus: This is incorrect. The palmaris longus tendon runs from the forearm to the palm and is more centrally located in the wrist. It is a thin tendon that is absent in about 14% of the population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flexor carpi radialis is a superficial flexor muscle of the forearm with a prominent tendon that runs from the forearm to the base of the second and third metacarpals, playing a key role in wrist flexion and abduction.

choices.text: Interstitial lung disease
Scleroderma renal crisis

questions.text: Which among the following is more common in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis when compared to diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Esophageal dysmotility

 

Esophageal dysmotility is more commonly associated with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc), particularly as part of the CREST syndrome (Calcinosis, Raynaud's phenomenon, Esophageal dysmotility, Sclerodactyly, and Telangiectasia). This condition involves abnormalities in the motility of the esophagus, which can lead to difficulties in swallowing and gastroesophageal reflux.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Myopathy: While myopathy can occur in systemic sclerosis, it is not specifically more common in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis compared to the diffuse type.

 

Option C. Interstitial lung disease (ILD): ILD is actually more commonly associated with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis due to broader and more aggressive skin involvement and higher prevalence of specific autoantibodies like Anti-Scl-70 (anti-topoisomerase).

 

Option D. Scleroderma renal crisis: This is a severe complication more frequently seen in diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis, particularly in the early stages of the disease, often exacerbated by the use of corticosteroids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/ Chap 360

questions.text: A female patient presents with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and loss of smell. On examination, foul-smelling discharge and yellowish-green crusts are present in the nasal cavity. She is found to have merciful anosmia. Which of the following finding can also be seen during the examination of her nose? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Roomy nasal cavity

 

ATROPHIC RHINITIS:

 

Pathology - Ciliated columnar epithelium is lost and is replaced by stratified squamous type. There is atrophy of seromucinous glands, venous blood sinusoids and nerve elements. Arteries in the mucosa, periosteum and bone show obliterative endarteritis. The bone of turbinates undergoes resorption causing widening of nasal chambers. Paranasal sinuses are small due to their arrested development.

 

Clinical Features

 

  1. Commonly seen in females and starts around puberty
  2. Foul smell from the nose though the patient himself is unaware of the smell due to marked anosmia (merciful anosmia) which accompanies these degenerative changes.
  3. Patients may complain of nasal obstruction due to large crusts filling the nose.
  4. Epistaxis may occur when the crusts are removed.

 

On examination shows

 

  1. Nasal cavity to be full of greenish or grayish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum. Attempts to remove them may cause bleeding.
  2. When the crusts have been removed, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates.
  3. Nasal mucosa appears pale. Septal perforation and dermatitis of nasal vestibule may be present. Nose may show a saddle deformity.
  4.  Atrophic changes may also be seen in the pharyngeal mucosa larynx.
  5. Hearing impairment may be noticed because of obstruction to the eustachian tube and middle ear effusion.
  6. Paranasal sinuses are usually small and underdeveloped with thick walls.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Nasal irrigation - using warm saline or an alkaline solution composed of sodium bicarbonate 1 part, sodium biborate 1 part, sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water
  • Local antibiotics - Kemicetine antiozaena solution containing chloromycetin, estradiol, and vitamin D2.
  • 25% glucose in glycerine, estradiol spray, systemic use of streptomycin, potassium iodide, placental extract.

 

Surgical management:

 

  • Young's operation: In this procedure, flaps are raised within the nasal vestibule and both the nostrils are completely closed and are opened after 6 months. During this time, the mucosa may revert to normal and the crusting is reduced.
  • Modified young's operation: In this procedure, the nostrils are partially closed and thereby avoiding the discomfort from complete closure of the nostrils. The results are the same compared to Young's operation.
  • Narrowing of the nasal cavity can be done by submucosal injection of Teflon paste, or by insertion of fat, cartilage, or Teflon strips under the mucoperiosteum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nasal polyps: These are non-neoplastic masses of the edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. Nasal polyps can be antrochoanal polyps or ethmoidal polyps.

 

Option C. Inferior turbinate hypertrophy: It is associated with various mucosal diseases which include allergic rhinitis, infectious rhinitis, and vasomotor rhinitis. It can cause chronic nasal obstruction.

 

Option D. Foreign body nose: It is commonly seen in children and the child presents with unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrophic rhinitis leads to significant structural changes within the nasal cavity, most notably an enlargement of the space due to bone and soft tissue atrophy. Recognizing these changes is crucial for diagnosing and managing the condition effectively, with treatments often focusing on moisturizing the nasal cavity and addressing the underlying atrophic changes.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 172, 173

questions.text: Shoulder dystocia is defined as delay in delivery of shoulders after delivery of head by? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 60 sec

 

Shoulder dystocia is technically defined as a delay in delivery of shoulders for more than 60 seconds after delivery of the head. 

 

Once the head is delivered and external rotation/restitution occurs, if the anterior shoulder doesn't deliver with gentle traction, maneuvers to relieve shoulder dystocia should be initiated immediately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Shoulder dystocia has two definitions:

 

  1. Technical: Delay in shoulder delivery >60 seconds after head delivery
  2. Practical: Need for additional maneuvers beyond gentle traction to deliver shoulders after head delivery
  3. Turtle Sign: Seen in Shoulder dystocia

questions.text: An adult female came with curdy white vaginal discharge. Microscopic examination showed gram-positive budding yeast and pseudohyphae. What can be the causative organism? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candida albicans

 

The key points indicate Candida albicans as the causative organism are:

 

  1. The patient presented with curdy white vaginal discharge, which is a common symptom of candidiasis (yeast infection).
  2. Microscopic examination revealed gram-positive budding yeast and pseudohyphae, which are characteristic of Candida albicans.
  3. Pseudohyphae are elongated structures with constrictions at the septal junctions, distinguishing them from true hyphae found in molds.
  4. Among the options provided, Candida albicans is the only fungus that forms pseudohyphae.

 

Candida albicans is a yeast that can cause various fungal infections, including vaginal candidiasis (commonly known as a "yeast infection"). The formation of pseudohyphae, along with budding yeast cells, is a distinctive feature of Candida albicans observed under the microscope.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bacterial vaginosis: This condition is caused by an overgrowth of various bacteria, not a fungus like Candida albicans.

 

Option C. Trichomoniasis: This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan parasite Trichomonas vaginalis, not a fungus.

 

Option D.  Gonorrhoea: Caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae, presents with purulent discharge but does not produce yeast or pseudohyphae. Diagnosis is typically confirmed with gram stain and culture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candida albicans is a fungus that can cause vaginal candidiasis (yeast infection), characterized by a curdy white vaginal discharge. The presence of gram-positive budding yeast and pseudohyphae on microscopic examination is a distinctive feature of Candida albicans infections.

questions.text: An Intraoperative image of MRM (Modified Radical Mastectomy) is shown. What nerve is marked? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Median pectoral nerve

 

During a modified radical mastectomy, careful identification and preservation of nerves is crucial to avoid postoperative complications. In this question, the nerve marked runs on the pectoralis minor muscle. This positioning is characteristic of the medial pectoral nerve, which supplies both the pectoralis minor and major muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Long thoracic nerve: This nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle and runs along the chest wall, passing vertically on the serratus anterior muscle, not the pectoralis minor.

 

Option B. Thoracodorsal nerve: This nerve supplies the latissimus dorsi muscle. It is found on the posterior chest wall and runs close to the latissimus dorsi, not along the pectoralis minor.

 

Option D. Subscapular nerve: This nerve innervates muscles such as the subscapularis, teres major, and latissimus dorsi. It is positioned more posteriorly and does not typically run along the pectoralis minor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of a modified radical mastectomy, the medial pectoral nerve runs on the pectoralis minor muscle, distinguishing it from other nerves that are positioned on different muscles in the thoracic region.

questions.text: A G2P1L1 with a previous cesarean section now presents at term. Which of the following is most favorable for a vaginal birth? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Previous lower segment cesarean

 

Explanation:

 

The type of uterine incision from a previous cesarean section significantly impacts the safety and likelihood of a successful vaginal birth after caesarean (VBAC).

 

The lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) involves a transverse incision made in the lower, thinner part of the uterus. This type of incision is most favorable for a vaginal birth due to its lower risk of uterine rupture during labor, which is around 0.2%.

 

Other Options:

 

Other Incision Types and Associated Risks:

 

Option A. Previous upper segment cesarean: This is also known as a classical cesarean section, where the incision is made vertically in the thicker, upper part of the uterus. The risk of uterine rupture with this type of incision is significantly higher, ranging from 4-9%.

 

Option C. Previous J-shaped cesarean: This incision extends from the lower segment into the upper segment, increasing the risk of rupture to 4-9%.

 

Option D. Previous T-shaped cesarean: This incision combines a lower segment transverse incision with a vertical extension into the upper segment, also associated with a 4-9% risk of rupture.

 

Educational objective:

 

The most favorable incision for a vaginal birth after a previous cesarean section is the lower segment transverse incision due to its lower risk of uterine rupture during labor.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents to the OPD. She had itchy lesions on her arm as shown with a family history of asthma. What could be the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atopic dermatitis

 

  • The image displays scratch marks and excoriations caused by pruritic lesions at a flexural site. The patient has a personal history of chronic and recurrent course, and there is also a family history of atopy, specifically asthma. These findings suggest a diagnosis of atopic dermatitis (AD) or atopic eczema (AE).

 

Atopic dermatitis (AD):

 

  • It is a chronic inflammatory condition that tends to persist or exhibit chronic relapses.
  • In infants, the first site of involvement is often the face.
  • Flexural distribution is observed in both the childhood and adult phases of the condition, while in the infantile phase, extensor distribution is more typical.

 

Atopic eczema can be divided into 3 phases:

 

  1. Infantile
  2. Childhood
  3. Adult

 

 

Atopic eczema infantile variant with face affected:

 

 

  • Atopic dermatitis typically presents with erythematous papules or papulovesicular lesions, often appearing in early childhood.
  • As the condition progresses, the lesions may evolve into excoriated and lichenified areas. Atopic dermatitis is commonly associated with secondary infections and skin dryness.
  • In the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis, the UK refinement of the Hanifin & Rajka criteria is employed.

 

UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (Eczema).

 

  • An itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child)
  • Plus, three or more of the following
    1. Onset below age 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
    2. History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
    3. History of a generally dry skin
    4. Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first degree relative in children under 4 years)
    5. Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/ forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

 

Clinical features of AD include:

 

  • Dennie-morgan fold under lower eyelid
  • Allergic shiners – periorbital pigmentation
  • Allergic salute – horizontal groove on dorsum of nasal bridge

 

 

Fig: Dennie-morgan fold

 

Complications of AD:

 

  • Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism to cause secondary infections in the lesions of atopic dermatitis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Seborrheic dermatitis:

 

  • This is a chronic condition that primarily affects sebum-rich areas of the body such as the scalp, face, and central chest.
  • It's characterized by yellowish, greasy scales and underlying erythema as shown in the image below.

 

 

 

  • While it can be itchy, its distribution and features are different from the description given.
  • There is no direct association between seborrheic dermatitis and a family history of asthma.

 

Option C. Allergic contact dermatitis:

  • This results from direct skin contact with allergens. It's an immunological response to a substance the individual has become sensitized to.
  • The lesions would be more correlated with contact to specific allergens, and it's not typically chronic or recurrent unless there is repeated exposure to the same allergen.
  • The distribution would be more in line with areas that contacted the allergen, rather than the typical flexural pattern described.

 

Option D. Erysipelas:

  • Erysipelas is an acute bacterial skin infection, typically caused by Group A Streptococcus.
  • It presents as a well-demarcated, raised, erythematous, and tender skin lesion, often accompanied by systemic symptoms like fever.
  • This condition is acute, not chronic or recurrent as described in the scenario.
  • There's no association with a family history of asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atopic dermatitis is a chronic, pruritic inflammatory skin disease commonly associated with flexural distribution of eczematous lesions and a family history of atopic conditions, such as asthma.

 

References:

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume 2 Chapter 41 page no 41.1, 41.2, 41.13-19

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume 3 Chapter 149 page no 149.21

Online resources:

https://www.jaad.org/article/S0190-9622(13)01095-5/fulltext

Question Level – Intermediate

Question Id-7456 Unique Key-Q3994123

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of physiological vaginal discharge? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cyclical

 

Physiological vaginal discharge is characteristically cyclical in nature. Normal vaginal discharge varies throughout the menstrual cycle due to hormonal changes. The discharge increases during specific times such as around ovulation (due to peak rise of estrogen increasing secretory activity of cervical glands) and premenstrually (due to pelvic congestion and increased mucus secretion from hypertrophied endometrial glands). This cyclical pattern is a normal physiological response to hormonal fluctuations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foul smelling: This is incorrect. Normal physiological vaginal discharge is not foul smelling. Foul odor is typically associated with pathological conditions such as bacterial vaginosis which produces a fishy odor (positive whiff test with KOH) or trichomoniasis.

 

Option C. Dirty white in color: This is incorrect. Normal physiological vaginal discharge is described as colorless or white, not dirty white. Dirty white or gray-white discharge is more characteristic of bacterial vaginosis.

 

Option D. Adherent to the vaginal wall: This is incorrect. While normal discharge may coat the vaginal walls, discharge that is specifically described as "adherent to the vaginal wall" is a characteristic feature of bacterial vaginosis (homogenous white discharge that coats the vaginal walls), not physiological discharge.

 

Characteristics of Normal Vaginal Discharge

 

Normal physiological vaginal discharge is:

 

  • Colorless/white
  • Non-odorous
  • pH around 4.0 in reproductive age
  • Cyclical in nature related to menstrual cycle phases
  • Contains secretions from vulvar glands, vaginal glands, vaginal transudate and secretions from the cervix, endometrium and fallopian tubes
  • Contains normal flora including Lactobacilli, Streptococci, Staphylococci
  • Shows desquamated epithelial cells, WBCs and Lactobacilli on microscopy

 

Educational Objective:

 

Physiological vaginal discharge has a distinct cyclical pattern throughout the menstrual cycle, with increased secretion during ovulation and premenstrual periods, reflecting the normal hormonal fluctuations of the reproductive system.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents in surgery OPD with midline swelling in the neck. The swelling moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroglossal cyst

 

  • Pathology – Remnant of thyroglossal duct
  • Most common site – midline à Subhyoid
  • C/F – Presents in 2nd /3rd decade of life as midline neck swelling which moves up on tongue protrusion and on deglutition.
  • Treatment - Sistrunk’s operation
  • Long standing thyroglossal cyst has a risk of papillary carcinoma thyroid

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Branchial cyst: Failure of obliteration of branchial cleft. Cystic swelling (soft)- typically in a teenager. Swelling at upper 1/3rd + middle 1/3rd junction of sternocleidomastoid.

 

 

Option C. Plunging ranula: Presents as Swelling in floor of mouth, Fluctuation present, Brilliant transillumination.

 

 

Option D. Dermoid cyst: Caused when skin and skin structures become trapped during fetal development.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A midline neck swelling that moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue is characteristic of a thyroglossal cyst, which is a remnant of the thyroglossal duct.
  • The treatment is typically surgical removal via the Sistrunk procedure.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presents with a history of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), sensorineural hearing loss. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital rubella

 

The classic triad of congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) includes:

 

  • Patent ductus arteriosus (cardiac defect)
  • Sensorineural hearing loss (auditory defect)
  • Cataract/salt and pepper retinopathy (ocular defect)

 

The presence of PDA and sensorineural hearing loss strongly suggests congenital rubella infection. This occurs when a pregnant woman contracts rubella virus during pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester when organogenesis is occurring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV): Though it can cause sensorineural hearing loss, it typically presents with microcephaly, periventricular calcifications, and hepatosplenomegaly rather than PDA.

 

Option C. Congenital toxoplasmosis: Classical features include hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications, and chorioretinitis. PDA is not a typical finding.

 

Option D. Congenital herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection: Usually presents with vesicular skin lesions, encephalitis, and keratoconjunctivitis. PDA and hearing loss are not typical features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital rubella syndrome is characterized by the triad of 

 

  • Patent ductus arteriosus (cardiac defect)
  • Sensorineural hearing loss (auditory defect)
  • Cataract/salt and pepper retinopathy (ocular defect)

questions.text: Which gene or protein deficiency is associated with Marfan’s Syndrome? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Fibrillin-1

 

Explanation: 

 

Marfan syndrome is caused by an inherited defect in the fibrillin-1 gene (FBN1), which maps to chromosomal locus 15q21. More than 1000 distinct causative mutations in the FBN1 gene have been found. Fibrillin is secreted by fibroblasts and is the major component of microfibrils found in the extracellular matrix. These microfibrils serve as scaffolds for the deposition of tropoelastin, an integral component of elastic fibers. The abnormal fibrillin protein acts as a dominant negative, preventing the assembly of normal microfibrils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fibrillin 2 - While fibrillin-2 is related to fibrillin-1 and has similar functions in the extracellular matrix, mutations in fibrillin-2 are associated with congenital contractural arachnodactyly (CCA), not Marfan syndrome.

 

Option C. Collagen - Defects in collagen are associated with other connective tissue disorders such as Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, not Marfan syndrome. Different variants of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome are caused by mutations in different collagen genes.

 

Option D. Elastin - While elastin interacts with fibrillin in elastic fibers, defects in elastin are associated with supravalvular aortic stenosis and Williams syndrome, not Marfan syndrome.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Marfan syndrome results from mutations in the FBN1 gene encoding fibrillin-1, which disrupts microfibril formation and leads to excessive TGF-β signaling, resulting in the classic manifestations of skeletal abnormalities, ocular defects, and cardiovascular complications.

choices.text: Wilson's disease
Autoimmune hepatitis
Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency

questions.text: A 55 yr old man is found to have hepatomegaly on physical examination. He also complains of dark tan despite avoiding sun exposure. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. This patient most likely suffers from: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemochromatosis

 

The patient most likely has hemochromatosis. The liver microscopy image in the given scenario shows hepatocellular iron deposition is dark-brown in H&E stain (A) and blue in Prussian blue-stained section (B).

 

 

Hemochromatosis is defined by an abnormally high accumulation of body iron, the majority of which is deposited in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas. Iron can also build up in the heart, joints, and endocrine systems.

 

Hemochromatosis, also known as primary or hereditary hemochromatosis, is an inherited disorder caused by excessive iron absorption.

 

Secondary hemochromatosis, acquired hemochromatosis, or hemosiderosis refers to the accumulation of iron in tissues as a result of parenteral iron administration, usually in the form of transfusions, or other causes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wilson's disease: Primarily involves copper accumulation in the liver and other tissues, leading to liver disease and neuropsychiatric symptoms.

 

Option B. Autoimmune hepatitis: Characterized by inflammation of the liver due to autoimmune disorders, not associated with iron deposition.

 

Option C. Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency: Leads to liver and lung disease due to the accumulation of abnormal alpha-1 antitrypsin protein in the liver, not iron.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemochromatosis is characterized by excessive iron deposition in the liver and other organs, which can be confirmed by the distinct staining patterns seen in liver biopsy samples.

questions.text: During a police investigation, bones are uncovered at the crime scene. What key characteristic feature would be crucial in differentiating between human and animal bones, aiding forensic analysis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Precipitin test

 

When differentiating between human and animal bones found at a crime scene, the key characteristic feature that aids forensic analysis is the species-specific differentiation. In such cases, regardless of the type of tissue (e.g., blood, semen, tissues, or bone), the precipitin test is the test of choice. In the precipitin test, an extract of the bone, tissue, or stain is taken, and an anti-human serum is added to it. If the sample is of human origin, a precipitate will form, indicating a positive result for human tissue.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option. B. Acid phosphatase: Acid phosphatase is a specific test used for detecting semen and is not relevant for differentiating between human and animal bones.

 

Option. C. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase): LDH is another test used for detecting semen and is not applicable for differentiating between human and animal bones.

 

Option. D. Phenolphthalein test : This test is a presumptive test to detect blood stain. Also known as (Kastle-Meyer) test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The precipitin test is the key characteristic feature used to differentiate between human and animal bones found at a crime scene. This test is species-specific and can be applied to various tissues, including blood, semen, and bones. The formation of a precipitate upon the addition of an anti-human serum to the sample extract indicates the presence of human tissue.

questions.text: A South Asian fruit farmer presented with fever, breathlessness, and encephalitis. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nipah virus

 

The Nipah virus is known to be transmitted by fruit bats, specifically the Pteropus species, which are commonly found in South Asia. The virus can cause severe respiratory illness and encephalitis in humans, symptoms that match the presentation in this case (fever, breathlessness, and encephalitis). The close association between fruit farming and fruit bats increases the risk of transmission, especially in South Asia where the Nipah virus is more prevalent.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zika virus: Zika virus is primarily transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes and is known for causing fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis. It does not cause severe respiratory symptoms or encephalitis as described in this case.

 

Option C. Malaria: Malaria is caused by Plasmodium species and transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes. It presents with fever, chills, and other systemic symptoms, but it does not typically cause breathlessness or encephalitis.

 

Option D. Ebola virus: Although Ebola can be associated with bats, it primarily causes hemorrhagic fever and is less associated with respiratory symptoms or encephalitis compared to Nipah virus. Also, Ebola is more commonly linked with direct human-to-human transmission or through contact with infected animals' bodily fluids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nipah virus should be considered when a patient, especially in South Asia, presents with fever, respiratory symptoms, and encephalitis, and has a history of exposure to fruit bats

questions.text: Gastric antral vascular ectasia is responsible for which of the following appearances? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Watermelon stomach.

 

Explanation:

 

Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE) is characterized by its distinctive endoscopic appearance resembling the stripes of a watermelon, hence the name "watermelon stomach." This condition features linear red streaks arranged in a radial pattern around the antrum of the stomach. These streaks represent dilated mucosal blood vessels that can cause chronic blood loss and iron deficiency anemia. GAVE is often associated with certain systemic conditions including portal hypertension, autoimmune disorders, and chronic renal failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Washerman stomach: This is not a recognized term for any specific gastric endoscopic finding. It does not describe the appearance of gastric antral vascular ectasia.

 

Option C. Windmill stomach: This is not a recognized term in gastroenterology for describing the appearance of gastric lesions or vascular abnormalities.

 

Option D. Windshield stomach: This is not a recognized term for any specific gastric endoscopic finding. It is not used to describe gastric antral vascular ectasia or any other known gastric condition.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Gastric antral vascular ectasia produces a characteristic endoscopic appearance called "watermelon stomach" with red stripes resembling a watermelon, representing dilated blood vessels that can cause chronic blood loss.

questions.text: A patient presented with sudden, painful diminution of vision, difficulty in vision in light, and circumferential congestion with hypopyon as shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute Anterior Uveitis

 

Acute Anterior Uveitis is an inflammatory condition affecting the uveal tract of the eye, particularly the anterior segment. It is characterized by the sudden onset of pain, redness, photophobia (difficulty seeing in bright light), and diminished vision. A key finding in this condition is the presence of hypopyon, which is the accumulation of inflammatory cells in the anterior chamber of the eye, settling at the bottom.

 

Key clinical signs of Acute Anterior Uveitis includes:

 

1. Hypopyon - The accumulation of white cells (pus) in the anterior chamber.

 

 

2. Circumferential congestion (ciliary flush) - Redness around the corneal edge.

 

 

3. Miotic (small) pupil - A constricted pupil which is not typical in other conditions listed.

 

4. Posterior synechiae, which is an adhesion between the iris and the lens. When attempting to dilate a pupil with posterior synechiae, a festooned (flower-shaped) pupil may result.

 

5. On the corneal endothelium, keratic precipitates (KPs), which are cellular aggregates with protein deposits, are a pathognomonic feature of uveitis.

 

 

6. Painful, diminished vision - Common in inflammatory eye conditions like uveitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Congestive Glaucoma: This condition involves elevated intraocular pressure, severe eye pain, and blurred vision. However, the pupil in acute glaucoma is usually mid-dilated and sluggish, not miotic, and hypopyon is not a feature of glaucoma.

 

Option C. Acute Conjunctivitis: Conjunctivitis primarily affects the conjunctiva, causing redness, irritation, and discharge. Hypopyon is not seen in conjunctivitis, and the condition is not typically associated with severe pain or vision changes seen in uveitis.

 

Option D. Episcleritis: Episcleritis is an inflammation of the episclera, leading to redness and mild discomfort. It usually affects one quadrant and is rarely associated with hypopyon or significant visual symptoms. The pupil size remains normal, and there is no severe pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute Anterior Uveitis is characterized by a painful red eye, circumcorneal congestion, hypopyon, and a miotic pupil, distinguishing it from other ocular conditions.

questions.text: The slowing of conduction in multiple sclerosis is due to which of the following? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Loss of myelin sheath

 

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is primarily characterized by the autoimmune-mediated demyelination of central nervous system neurons. The myelin sheath is crucial for proper and fast electrical conduction along nerve fibers; it facilitates saltatory conduction, which allows the action potential to jump rapidly from one node of Ranvier to the next. The loss of this myelin sheath in MS results in significantly slowed and disrupted nerve signal conduction, which underlies many of the neurological symptoms associated with the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gliosis: Gliosis is not seen in MS but seen in viral encephalitis, Alzheimer's disease, traumatic brain injury, and gliomas

 

Option C. Defect at node of Ranvier: Although alterations in the nodes of Ranvier occur secondary to demyelination, the primary issue is the loss of the myelin sheath itself, not initial defects at the nodes.
