Option D. Leaky Na+ channel: This option refers to a specific type of channelopathy that isn't characteristic of MS. In MS, the problem is more about the insulation (myelin) around the nerve fibers rather than the ion channels within the nerve cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple sclerosis is characterized by demyelination that results in loss of saltatory conduction occurring from one node of Ranvier to the other.

 

Reference - Harrison/Multiple sclerosis/Chap 444

choices.text: Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady presents with third degree uterine prolapse. Which of the following is the best management for her?( NEET PG 2019 )
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

 

Explanation

 

  • In the given case scenario, vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair is the ideal management.
  • This is also called as Ward Mayo repair
  • This is recommended to patients who satisfy the following criteria:
    • >40 years of age
    • Have completed their families
    • Do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fothergill repair: This is also known as Manchester repair and involves conserving the uterus. In this procedure, cervical amputation with plication of the cardinal ligaments is done. It is done in young women who have completed their families with utero-vaginal prolapse.

 

Option B. Sling operation: This is preferred in women who are young, nulliparous (yet to have children/ complete their families) with prolapse

 

Option D. Shirodkar procedure: This is a modification of Manchester/ Fothergill surgery and does not include cervical amputation

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair (Ward Mayo repair) is the preferred management for older women (>40 years) with third degree uterine prolapse who have completed their families and do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function.

 

Ref: Page 221, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Amsel criteria is used for? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bacterial vaginosis

 

Explanation:

 

Amsel's criteria are used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis (BV). The diagnosis requires at least three out of the following four criteria to be present:

 

  1. Homogeneous, thin, white discharge that smoothly coats the vaginal walls.
  2. Clue cells on microscopy: Vaginal epithelial cells that appear stippled with bacteria.
  3. Positive whiff test: A fishy odor is released when a solution of 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) is added to a sample of the vaginal discharge.
  4. Vaginal pH > 4.5: An elevated pH is indicative of BV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Candidiasis: Diagnosed primarily by clinical presentation and microscopic identification of yeast cells or pseudo hyphae.

 

Option C. Cervicitis: Diagnosed based on clinical findings and specific laboratory tests for pathogens like Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

 

Option D. Trichomoniasis: Diagnosed by identifying the flagellated protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis on a wet mount microscopy or by specific antigen tests.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amsel criteria are specifically used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis, requiring the presence of at least three out of four specific clinical and laboratory findings.

questions.text: A patient came to emergency with severe breathlessness. CXR is taken and shown below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pleural effusion

 

Explanation:

 

The chest X-ray (CXR) of the patient shows a whiteout on one side with a significant tracheal shift to the opposite side. These findings are indicative of a massive pleural effusion.

 

Pleural effusion: This condition results in the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space, leading to lung compression and a shift of the mediastinum, including the trachea, away from the affected side. The presence of a large whiteout on the X-ray, along with the tracheal deviation to the opposite side, strongly suggests pleural effusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: This condition would typically present with a hyperlucent (dark) area on the X-ray without lung markings, rather than a whiteout. It also generally causes a tracheal shift towards the opposite side, but the appearance on the X-ray would be different.

 

Option B. Consolidation: This condition involves filling of the alveoli with fluid or other material, leading to a whiteout appearance on the X-ray. However, it does not usually cause a significant tracheal shift.

 

Option C. Collapse: This condition, also known as atelectasis, would cause a shift of the trachea towards the affected side. It can present with a whiteout on the X-ray, but the tracheal deviation would be opposite to that seen in pleural effusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A massive pleural effusion is characterized by a whiteout on the chest X-ray with a significant tracheal shift to the opposite side.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with abdominal pain, weight loss, and jaundice. Imaging studies reveal a mass arising from the antrum of the stomach extending into the head of the pancreas with metastasis to the right lobe of the liver. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy

 

  • The clinical scenario involves carcinoma stomach infiltrating into the pancreas with liver metastasis.
  • Palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy is the management of choice for such cases.
  • It is a type of palliative surgery that relieves the symptoms of gastric outlet obstruction caused by tumors in the distal stomach or duodenum.
  • The procedure allows food to bypass the obstruction and enter the small intestine, improving the patient's ability to eat and preventing malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option B. Radical gastrectomy: Radical gastrectomy involves the surgical removal of the stomach with the aim of curing the disease. This option is typically considered for localized gastric cancer that has not metastasized extensively.

 

Option C. Whipple's procedure (Pancreaticoduodenectomy): The Whipple's procedure is a complex surgical operation that involves the removal of the head of the pancreas, the duodenum, a portion of the bile duct, and sometimes part of the stomach. It is typically performed for cancers located in the head of the pancreas, not stomach cancer.

 

Option D. Gastrectomy with right hepatectomy: This surgical approach involves the removal of the stomach (gastrectomy) and the right lobe of the liver. It might be considered if the tumor is locally advanced and involves both the stomach and liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For patients with advanced gastric cancer extending into adjacent organs and with liver metastasis, the appropriate management often involves palliative measures, such as gastrojejunostomy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life, followed by chemotherapy.
  • Curative surgical options are generally not feasible in the presence of metastasis.

questions.text: Central venules have which type of cells in the center? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) RBCs


The central venules are part of the vascular system where blood flow dynamics play a crucial role in cell distribution. The concept of parabolic flow describes how blood components are distributed within the vessel. In this flow pattern, the velocity of the blood is highest at the center of the vessel and decreases towards the periphery.

 

  • RBCs (Red Blood Cells): Due to their biconcave shape and flexibility, RBCs tend to move towards the center of the vessel where the flow velocity is highest. This central position allows them to travel efficiently through the bloodstream without being impeded by the endothelial cells lining the vessel walls.
  • WBCs (White Blood Cells): These cells, which include lymphocytes, neutrophils, and macrophages, are larger and less flexible compared to RBCs. As a result, they are often found closer to the vessel walls where the flow velocity is lower. This positioning is also influenced by the process of margination, where WBCs move towards and interact with the endothelial cells, particularly during inflammation.
  • Platelets: Although smaller than RBCs, platelets have an irregular shape and tend to get trapped in the spaces between endothelial cells, preventing them from flowing freely in the center of the vessel.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymphocytes and B. Neutrophils:  Types of WBC, tend to be located near the vessel walls due to their larger size and the process of margination.

 

Option C. Macrophages: These are larger WBCs involved in immune responses and are usually found in the periphery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In central venules, RBCs are found in the center due to their shape, flexibility, and the dynamics of parabolic flow.

questions.text: A 45-year-old forest ranger presents with sudden onset high fever, severe headache, and a characteristic rash that began on his trunk and spread to his extremities suspecting typhus (rickettsial) infection, a Weil-Felix test is performed using Proteus antigens. What type of antigen is used in this test? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heterophile antigen

 

The Weil-Felix test uses Proteus antigens to diagnose rickettsial infections because Proteus shares epitopes with Rickettsia. These shared epitopes allow antibodies produced against rickettsial antigens to cross-react with Proteus antigens. This type of cross-reactivity between antigens from different species is called heterophile antigenicity.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Isoantigen: Refers to antigens that are identical within the same species. 

 

Option B. Superantigen: These are antigens that cause non-specific T-cell activation. 

 

Option D. Sequestered antigen: These are normally hidden from the immune system.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Heterophile antigens are antigens from different species that share epitopes, allowing cross-reactivity in diagnostic tests like the Weil-Felix test.

questions.text: Which type of aphasia is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fluent aphasia

 

The posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus is where Wernicke's area is located, which is crucial for language comprehension. Lesions in this area lead to Wernicke's aphasia, which is a type of fluent aphasia. Patients with this type of aphasia exhibit fluent but often meaningless speech and have significant difficulties in understanding spoken language. Their speech is typically characterized by normal flow and articulation but includes nonsensical phrases and incorrect word substitutions (neologisms).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Non-fluent aphasia: This type of aphasia, typically associated with damage to Broca’s area in the frontal lobe, results in slow, labored speech and struggle in forming words, though comprehension often remains intact.

 

Option C. Anomic aphasia: In anomic aphasia, the person can speak fluently and understand speech but has difficulty naming objects and words, typically not linked to damage in the superior temporal gyrus.

 

Option D. Conduction aphasia: This arises from damage to the arcuate fasciculus, the brain structure that connects Wernicke's area to Broca’s area. It is characterized by fluent speech with frequent errors, good comprehension, but poor repetition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Regions anterior to the central sulcus are motor areas and posterior are sensory areas. Hence temporal gyrus involvement causes a fluent aphasia.

 

 

Reference - KV Krishna Das textbook of Medicine 5th edition
